name: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
summary: A structured, short-term form of couples and family therapy that focuses on identifying, understanding, and transforming negative interaction patterns while strengthening emotional bonds.
description: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT) is an evidence-based therapeutic approach developed by Dr. Sue Johnson in the 1980s. It is grounded in attachment theory and aims to help couples and families create secure emotional bonds by identifying and restructuring interactional patterns that create distress. EFT focuses on helping individuals express underlying attachment needs and emotions in a safe and supportive environment. By fostering secure emotional connections, EFT reduces conflict, enhances communication, and improves relationship satisfaction. EFT has three stages: de-escalation of negative cycles, restructuring interactions through emotional engagement, and consolidation of new, healthier patterns.

conditions_treated: Secondary depression or anxiety from relationship strain
off_label_uses: Support for trauma recovery through attachment repair
Improving therapeutic alliance in individual therapy
contraindications: Active substance dependence without concurrent treatment
Severe psychiatric instability in one or more participants
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and supportive when applied by trained clinicians. Minimal risk beyond typical therapy challenges.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High—supported by numerous randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Meta-analyses show EFT is highly effective in improving relationship satisfaction, reducing distress, and promoting long-term relationship stability.

sections.text: EFT works by helping partners identify destructive interaction cycles, express unmet attachment needs, and create corrective emotional experiences that foster secure bonding. It leverages attachment theory to restructure relationship dynamics, strengthen empathy, and build new communication patterns.

sections.preparation: Assessment of relationship dynamics and attachment history.
procedure: Stage 1: De-escalation – identifying negative interaction cycles and reframing issues in terms of underlying emotions and attachment needs.
Stage 2: Restructuring interactions – fostering emotional engagement and creating new positive bonding experiences.
Stage 3: Consolidation – integrating new interaction patterns and solidifying secure attachment bonds.
sections.duration: 8–20 sessions depending on severity of issues and goals.

sections.pre_session: Review of recent interactions and emotional triggers.
sections.treatment_phase: Facilitated emotional exploration, interaction restructuring, and empathy-building exercises.
sections.post_session: Homework may involve practicing new communication patterns or emotional check-ins.

uncommon: Temporary increase in conflict as deeper issues are surfaced

ideal_candidates: Couples seeking to rebuild trust and intimacy
Families with persistent cycles of conflict
screening_required: Assessment of safety in the relationship
Evaluation of readiness to engage in emotionally focused work

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained and certified in EFT
facility: Private practice, mental health clinics, or online therapy platforms

studies: Johnson SM, et al. (1999). Emotionally Focused Couple Therapy: Status and challenges. Clinical Psychology: Science and Practice.
Wiebe SA, Johnson SM. (2016). A review of the research in Emotionally Focused Therapy for couples. Family Process.
sections.limitations: Most research is on couples; fewer studies on families or non-romantic relationships.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies depending on session count (average $1,500–$3,500 total)
sections.insurance_coverage: Sometimes covered under family or couples therapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective due to relatively brief treatment with durable effects.

concurrent_therapies: Individual therapy for trauma or mood disorders
lifestyle_recommendations: Practicing vulnerability and empathy outside of therapy

sections.couples: Effective across diverse populations, including same-sex couples.
sections.families: Adaptations available for family therapy contexts.

items: One of the most evidence-based couples therapies available.
Relapse prevention requires ongoing practice of new communication patterns.
Strong emphasis on creating secure attachment bonds.

items.label: Johnson SM. (2004). The Practice of Emotionally Focused Couple Therapy: Creating Connection.
International Centre for Excellence in Emotionally Focused Therapy (ICEEFT).

seo.title: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT) for Couples and Families
seo.description: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT) is an evidence-based couples and family therapy focused on attachment, emotional bonding, and resolving negative interaction patterns.
